0: Former WikiLeaks Members Form “Openleaks” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Do you like this story? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR As WikiLeaks and its leader Julian Assange face mounting legal issues, key members of the project are reportedly jumping ship. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR According to the Swedish news site DN.se, the new project, dubbed Openleaks, is going to launch Monday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR An insider told DN.se, “The two organizations are similar in that aspect that both are focusing on providing means for whistleblowers to anonymously provide the public with information.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Where the two services will differ, it appears, is both from a management and publishing perspective. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There were reports of internal strife within WikLeaks even before Assange’s arrest earlier this week. In October, The New York Times published a profile on Assange with some accounts from former members of the project. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR We don’t know if any of those defectors are members of Openleaks, but the criticism lobbed against the controversial figure is the same. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Perhaps the most striking difference between the two projects, at least as we know them right now, is how information is actually disseminated. Rather than publishing documents directly, Openleaks instead seeks to be an intermediary between whistleblowers and other organizations. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR An insider told DN.se: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “All editorial control and responsibility rests with the publishing organization. We will, as far as possible, take the role of the messenger between the whistleblower and the organization the whistleblower is trying to cooperate with.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The source continued: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “As a result of our intention not to publish any document directly and in our own name, we do not expect to experience the kind of political pressure which WikiLeaksWikileaks is under at this time. In that aspect, it is quite interesting to see how little of politicians’ anger seems directed at the newspapers using WikiLeaks sources.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On the one hand, yes, simply acting as a broker of sensitive information may constitute less legal or political pressures for an organization. On the other hand, it raises important questions about what kinds of organizations are allowed to access the system and how that access is determined. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Openleaks can claim to be “without a political agenda,” but that doesn’t negate the fact that acting as a gatekeeper is in and of itself a political statement. role lobbed legal NEWLINE_CHAR “The Openleaks, differ, quite
